prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B8 continuum: Dust-poor AGNs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This project is designed to image hot dust-poor AGNs at band 8. This a straightforward continuum project to measure the redshited rest-FIR flux, and define the source position of star formation with respect to that of the optical AGN counterpart. The field was entered by uploading an ASCII field into the Field Setup node of the Science Goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will observe a subset of hot dust-poor quasars that are observable from the southern hemisphere (Dec < +15 deg), and at z > 2.5 to determine FIR emission component with the ALMA band coverage. We also exclude radio-loud quasars whose FIR continuum is very likely to be dominated by the radio emission. We will target 5 of them for this study that are clustered within 10 degree circle on the sky or at the highest redshift. The proposed observation will determine the amount of FIR-emission by detecting the FIR continuum from these quasars in multiple-bands. The ALMA band-8 and band-6 sample the rest-frame wavelengths of 160 and 325 micron at z=3, making it possible to determine the slope of the FIR emission and estimate the FIR flux contribution to a reasonable accuracy through SED-fitting. The correlator setup will be set to maximize the continuum detection. We will use the default frequency coverage which seems to be maximized for the highest S/N continuum detection and the scheduling efficiency. The expected lower limit on the continuum flux can be derived by assuming the FIR emission to be as weak as the NIR dust emission. This is achieved by extrapolating the composite SED template of Richards et al. (2006), normalized at the 2.3 micron flux of targets. We estimate that the lower limits of the continuum fluxes to be within 0.4- 3 mJy at the band 8, and 0.2 - 1.5 mJy at the band 6 which can be detected at S/N > 3 with a few minutes of exposure time per band. The usage of ALMA is necessary, since no existing facilities can reach such faint flux limits in submm in a reasonable exposure time. Also, ALMA's high resolution makes it possible to determine the center of FIR emission to a great accuracy (0.1 arcsec), good enough for a statistical study of offsets between FIR and optical centers. Since our sources at high redshift, and are expected to have a size less than 1 arcsec, we will use the C34-6 to get the maximum resolution at the band 8. Similarly, C34-7 will be used for band 6. We will use default calbiration setup, and there is no special scheduling/time constraints.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Hot dust-poor quasars are luminous quasars which show exceptionally little hot dust emission in the rest-frame NIR. Almost no quasars are found to be hot dust-poor at z < 1, but recent works suggest that hot dust-poor quasars are 10 times or more abundant among luminous, high accretion rate quasars at z > 2. An intriguing possibility has been suggested that hot dust-poor quasars are the first generation of quasars in an early evolutionary stage where the dust torus has not had time to form due to the lack of dust in the early universe. However, other plausible explanations also exist, in which hot dust-poor quasars are not necessarily poor in dust at FIR With ALMA, we propose to detect the rest-frame FIR continuum and derive the amount of FIR dust emission in 4 hot dust-poor quasars at 2.5< z < 3.7 to see if they are in dust-poor environment. We will also investigate if hot dust-poor quasars are related to recoiling SMBHs by searching for significant offsets between the center of the host galaxy light (as revealed by ALMA) and the center of the quasar light (in the optical).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Seoul National University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Seoul National University
